pages.text: Entelognathus is a genus of early placoderm from the Yunnan province of China during the upper Silurian. The specimens of the animal were exceptionally well preserved, being the tridimensional head and jaw, revealing that the placoderm had a premaxillary, maxillary, and dentary bone, not unlike those of other bony fish.

The tridimensionality of the fossils also revealed a strange characteristic quirk of the animal. Its eyes were fixed forward and angled downwards, giving the fish a dopey expression. It is unclear why it was like this, but it is hypothesized that the animal ate burying animals, like brachiopods, invertebrates, or small agnathan fish.
